headline.main: The Real Lessons of Enron's Fall

docs.snippet: An article in Business Day yesterday about questions from Democratic lawmakers about the effectiveness of regulators in light of the collapse of Enron misspelled the surname of the chief of staff for Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of Cal...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article in Business Day yesterday about questions from Democratic lawmakers about the effectiveness of regulators in light of the collapse of Enron misspelled the surname of the chief of staff for Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California. The aide, who said calls from Enron executives to members of President Bush's cabinet last fall should have prompted at least a preliminary investigation, is Philip M. Schiliro, not Schilaro.
docs.abstract: Correction of Jan 15 article, which misspelled name of Rep Henry A Waxman's aide, Philip M Schiliro

headline.main: The Fall of Enron: Messy Politics

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    ''Enron Contacted 2 Cabinet Officers Before Collapsing'' (front page, Jan. 11) indicates that the company, a contributor to George W. Bush's various campaigns, essentially dictated the terms of his administration's energy policy....
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Enron Contacted 2 Cabinet Officers Before Collapsing'' (front page, Jan. 11) indicates that the company, a contributor to George W. Bush's various campaigns, essentially dictated the terms of his administration's energy policy. Your article concludes by noting that certain recommendations included in the report issued by Vice President Dick Cheney's energy policy task force ''resembled much of what Enron had advocated'' in meetings at the Bush White House.
docs.abstract: Cheryl Davis letter calls for independent prosecutor to determine Enron's influence on Bush administration's energy policy (S)

headline.main: The Fall of Enron: Messy Politics

docs.snippet: The crash of the Enron Corporation, which landed the company in bankruptcy court two weeks ago, has lured lawyers like moths to a candle, sharks to a swimmer, hyenas to a carcass. In other words, a lot of lawyers. But Joseph D. Jamail Jr., one of ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The crash of the Enron Corporation, which landed the company in bankruptcy court two weeks ago, has lured lawyers like moths to a candle, sharks to a swimmer, hyenas to a carcass. In other words, a lot of lawyers. But Joseph D. Jamail Jr., one of the nation's most successful lawyers -- who just happens to live and work in Houston, Enron's hometown -- wants nothing to do with it. ''I really am glad to be uninvolved,'' said Mr. Jamail, who became a multimillionaire on fees from a record $10.5 billion jury verdict against Texaco for interfering with a planned investment by Pennzoil in Getty Oil in 1987.
docs.abstract: Joseph D Jamail Jr, Houston resident and one of most successful attorneys is US, is pleased not to be involved in Enron Corp litigation, calling it bottomless pit (S)

headline.main: Private Sector; Happy to Watch While Others Feed

byline.original: By Jonathan D. Glater (COMPILED BY RICK GLADSTONE)

docs.snippet: Enron's collapse leaves its 28,500 energy management customers, from upscale retailers and shopping malls to glass factories and steel mills, wondering whether they will soon have to find energy supplies on their own, and at what cost. In just the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Enron's collapse leaves its 28,500 energy management customers, from upscale retailers and shopping malls to glass factories and steel mills, wondering whether they will soon have to find energy supplies on their own, and at what cost. In just the last year, Enron signed billions of dollars' worth of long-term energy management contracts. Under those contracts, Enron generally pledged to provide its customers with electricity and natural gas, maintain generating, heating and cooling equipment, pursue conservation measures and protect against swings in energy prices. In November last year, the Macerich Company, based in Santa Monica, Calif., signed a 10-year agreement with Enron to provide electricity and natural gas for the 51 shopping malls it owns or operates, including the Queens Center, in Elmhurst, and the Redmond Town Center near Seattle. Then, Arthur Coppola, Macerich's president and chief executive, hailed the agreement, worth about $15 million a year, as a way to tame the volatility of energy prices.
docs.abstract: Enron's collapse leaves its 28,500 business customers having to look elsewhere for nautral gas, electricity and paper mill products; customers range from shopping malls to factories to newspapers (M)

headline.main: Energy Customers; With a Manager Gone, Gaps to Be Bridged

docs.snippet: OF all the scenes from the Enron train wreck, none is more disturbing than that of the workers dazed by the realization that their retirement plans have been destroyed by the plunge of their company's once highflying stock.     The only sins these...
docs.lead_paragraph: OF all the scenes from the Enron train wreck, none is more disturbing than that of the workers dazed by the realization that their retirement plans have been destroyed by the plunge of their company's once highflying stock. The only sins these men and women committed were being loyal to their company and wanting their own tiny version of the riches Enron executives habitually pocketed during their years at the company. Kenneth L. Lay has taken hundreds of millions of dollars out of Enron in recent years. Of Enron's 21,000 employees, the 12,000 or so who were in the Enron-laden 401(k) plan have virtually nothing.
docs.abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column notes that about 12,000 Enron Corp employees were in its 401(k) retirement plan laden with company's stock, which is now worth virtually nothing; suggests that it is time to review wisdom of loading one's pension plan with stock of one company, even one's employer's equities (M)

docs.snippet: The Enron Corporation, still struggling to reassure investors it can weather a financial crisis over complicated transactions involving its former chief financial officer, is seeking $1 billion to $2 billion in additional financing from banks, an ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation, still struggling to reassure investors it can weather a financial crisis over complicated transactions involving its former chief financial officer, is seeking $1 billion to $2 billion in additional financing from banks, an industry official said today. Last week, Enron, the nation's largest energy-trading concern, used about $3 billion in available credit lines and spent about $2 billion to pay off commercial paper. Now, by obtaining even more financing, Enron is hoping to convince investors and other energy-trading firms that it will not face a cash squeeze that could lead trading partners to refuse to extend credit or do business with it.
docs.abstract: Enron Corp, still struggling to reassure investors it can weather financial crisis over complicated transactions involving its former chief financial officer, is seeking $1 billion to $2 billion in additional financing from banks (S)

docs.snippet: ''Let them eat cake!'' cried the new president's friend, a key campaign supporter who was also a prominent advocate of bakery deregulation, not to mention the owner of a chain of cake shops.    O.K., not exactly. Kenneth Lay, chairman of Enron, wa...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Let them eat cake!'' cried the new president's friend, a key campaign supporter who was also a prominent advocate of bakery deregulation, not to mention the owner of a chain of cake shops. O.K., not exactly. Kenneth Lay, chairman of Enron, was a prime mover in George W. Bush's presidential campaign; he has also been an influential voice in favor of electricity deregulation, and Enron is profiting handsomely from the electricity it sells in California. But what he actually said was that California's power consumers ''need to see the price signals [that is, pay much more] and start modifying behavior to reduce demand until we get new supplies.'' He also rejected the plea of California officials for a federally imposed cap on wholesale electricity prices, arguing that this would merely ''start spreading the shortage around.'' And his friend the president has echoed his views.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column says a good case can be made for a federally imposed cap on wholesale electricity prices as a way to increase supplies in California in the short term and provide some much-needed financial relief to its utilities; says this does not mean that Californians should be shielded from higher prices needed to reduce consumption; notes that wholesale price cap is opposed by Kenneth Lay, a prime mover in George W Bush's presidential campaign and chairman of Enron, a Houston company that is profiting handsomely from electricity it sells in California (M)
